title: Drive Chain Replacement

body.body: Before starting work, ensure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported. This will help prevent it from falling and causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Chain Replacement EK Chain DD2; DE; DE2; DF; DF2; DS1; DSA; DSB; DSX
The following instructions for the replacement of rivet link type drive chains requires the use of
T3880635 - Final Drive Chain Cut and Rivet
Support the motorcycle on a stand so the rear wheel is clear of the ground.
Insert the cut/rivet pin into the pin holder so its smaller diameter end (cutting point) is facing away from the holder as shown.
If required, file the domed heads of the chain link pins flat.
so that the drive chain is between the cut/rivet pin and the service tool body, with the pin that is to be removed aligned with the hole in the service tool body.
Turn the pin holder clockwise until its pin contacts the link pin. Ensure that the pin is centralised on the link pin to be removed.
Retain the tool body and rotate the pin holder clockwise until the link pin is pressed out from the chain.
Remove the tool and separate the two ends of the chain.
The replacement chain is supplied in a split condition, complete with a link kit to join the two ends.
The component parts of the new link kit are coated with a special grease which must not be removed. Removal of this special grease will severely reduce the service life of the chain.
Do not use the new connector link as the special grease on it may be removed.

Use the old drive chain to pull the new chain into position as follows: Temporarily attach the end of the new chain to a free end of the old chain using the old connector link. Carefully pull the other end of the old chain to pull the new chain around the sprockets.
Using the new link supplied with the chain kit, join the two ends of the chain. Ensure that the O-rings are positioned as shown below and the link plate is fitted with its markings facing outwards.

body.name: New link for new chain camw

body.body: Insert the cut/rivet pin into the pin holder so its larger diameter end (riveting point) is facing away from holder as shown.
Fit the guide plate A to the service tool as shown below.
Fit the new connecting link plate to the new link by hand or with a suitable pair of pliers.
so that the new connecting link plate of the drive chain is in contact with guide plate A.
Rotate the pin holder clockwise until the drive chain link makes contact with guide plate B.
Ensure the connecting link is correctly positioned and then continue to rotate the pin holder to press the connecting link fully on.
Rotate the pin holder anticlockwise and remove the Guide plate A and insert the cut/rivet pin into the pin holder so its larger diameter end (riveting point) is facing away from the holder.

Align one of the split link pins to the cut/rivet pin then turn the pin holder clockwise until the pin contacts the split link pin. Ensure the split link pin is centrally located on the cut/rivet pin.
The riveting end of the cut/rivet pin is shaped to prevent over tightening. Over tightening may cause damage to the connecting link pin and the cut/rivet pin.
Retain the tool body then tighten the pin holder until the split link end is riveted-over.
Back off the pin holder and rivet the remaining split link pin as described above.
Remove the tool from the chain and using the gauge from
check that both the split link pins are correctly riveted. The rivet should not pass through the slot on the gauge.
Also check that both the split link pins are correctly riveted as shown below.

If either split link pin is not correctly riveted, the split link must be removed and replaced with a new link. Never operate the motorcycle with an incorrectly riveted split link as the link could fail resulting in an unsafe riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Before starting work, ensure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported. This will help prevent it from falling and causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Free the chain from the front sprocket and remove it from the motorcycle.
Locate the new chain on the front sprocket.
